I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Second Health Care in the Central Highlands 
Project.1  
 
2.  The central highlands lag most other regions of Viet Nam in terms of health and health 
services indicators toward Millennium Development Goals (MDGs).2 The project will help the 
government to further reduce maternal and child mortality by addressing access to and quality 
gaps in commune health stations (CHSs) and hospitals and by strengthening provincial health 
management in five provinces, thereby targeting the poor, ethnic groups, and women and 
children in particular.   
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale  
 
3.  The Government of Viet Nam is highly committed to providing health care for all its 
citizens. Viet Nam’s Socio-Economic Development Plan, 2011–2015 gives high priority to the 
health sector as a core pillar of sustainable socioeconomic development. Through its Five-Year 
Health Sector Development Plan, 2011–2015, the government seeks to develop an extended 
and robust health-care network. Emphasis is on access to primary health care in mountainous, 
remote, and isolated areas to enhance public health performance.3 Investing in primary health 
care helps prevent families slipping into poverty due to high out-of-pocket spending for higher 
level medical services, improves productivity, and addresses public goods and services with 
externalities.4   
 
4.  Poverty incidence remains high in the central highlands region of Viet Nam. The central 
highlands, which comprises the provinces of Dak Lak, Dak Nong, Gia Lai, Kon Tum, and Lam 
Dong, is changing rapidly  with strong economic growth and interregional and intraregional 
migration.5 However, poverty persists in particular among the ethnic groups, who constitute 38% 
of  the  region’s  population  of  5.3  million  people.  The  poor  comprise  22%  of  the  region’s 
population, 6 a figure  that  rises  to  51%  among the  region’s  ethnic groups.7 Nationally,  the 
poverty incidence is 14% (footnote 6). 
 
5.  Viet Nam’s impressive progress towards MDGs is held back by poor health indicators in 
the central and northern uplands, in particular for maternal and child mortality and especially in 
remote rural communities with ethnic groups. The national maternal mortality ratio (MMR) in 
2011 was 67 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births,8 still short of the MDG target of 58 in

2015.9 In the central highlands region, the MMR in 2009 was an estimated 108 and probably 
much higher among ethnic groups.10 The national infant mortality rate (IMR) was 15.5 deaths 
per 1,000 live births in 2011(footnote 8), and among ethnic groups, 30.0,11 also above the MDG 
target of 14.8 in 2015.12 In the central highlands, the 2011 IMR of the general population was 
24.3 (footnote 8). The national under-5 mortality rate (U5MR) was 23.3 deaths per 1,000 live 
births in 2011, and among ethnic groups, 39.0 (footnote 11), compared with an MDG target of 
19.3 (footnote 12). In the central highlands, the 2011 U5MR of the general population was 
37.0.13 While communicable diseases are becoming less prevalent in the region among the 
majority  Kinh  population,  ethnic groups  suffer  a  high  burden  of respiratory,  intestinal,  and 
parasitic infections that contribute to malnutrition, which is estimated to affect almost a quarter 
of the children below age 5 (footnote 8). 
 
6.  Nationally, the government has established a wide network of health services. The 
standard  public  health system comprises  CHSs,  district hospitals,  provincial  hospitals,  and 
national referral institutions. Recognizing constraints on accessibility, efficiency, and resources, 
the  government  has  added,  where  needed,  intercommunal  polyclinics  (ICPs),  interdistrict 
hospitals, and interprovincial (regional) hospitals.  
 
7.  To improve health care in the central highlands, the government has since the 1990s 
mobilized  state  bonds  and  external  assistance  toward  making  substantial  investments  in 
hospital development.14 The government has developed a network of health facilities in the 
central highlands region, including 71 hospitals,15 49 ICPs, and 722 CHSs, and preventive 
medicine facilities. The few small private hospitals and most private clinics are in urban areas.  
 
8.  Access to community health care and its quality. To help address the high burden of 
disease and mortality in villages, the Ministry of Health (MOH) supports information, education, 
and communication (IEC) programs; outreach services; village health workers (VHWs); and 
village birth attendants (VBAs). Most villages have at least one VHW, male or female, and a 
VBA. VBAs are expected to attend deliveries only in remote locations, otherwise refer patients 
for delivery in the CHS. The MOH has initiated a program to upgrade the skills of VHWs and 
VBAs with a 6-month training program, however, in-service training and the supervision of 
VHWs and VBAs need to be expanded and improved. VHWs and VBAs also lack basic supplies 
such as delivery kits.  
 
9.  CHSs are essential links in the care and referral chain from communities and hospitals, 
particularly for the poor and ethnic groups. In the central highlands, CHSs are underutilized: 
patients prefer to use public hospitals as first point of contact (footnote 6). The catchment areas 
of CHSs are twice as large as the national average because population density is low. CHSs 
may be bypassed if located close to a hospital. Many CHSs are small and in bad condition, 
sometimes operating in one room or rented premises, with facilities and equipment requiring

3 
 
upgrade or replacement. The MOH is planning to upgrade selected busy CHSs into ICPs to 
improve emergency care and relieve crowding in hospitals. This would require the provision of 
more advanced diagnostic equipment and basic inpatient facilities.  
 
10.  CHS quality is perceived as poor. The quality of care in CHSs is affected by the lack of 
skilled  staff,  standard  procedures,  and  quality  assurance.16 Only  65%  of  communes  met 
national  quality  assurance  benchmarks  in  2010  (footnote  8).  MOH  has  issued  clinical 
standards, but they are not adapted to local conditions and are not implemented at the CHS 
level.17 While most CHSs have core staff including a midwife, only 58% have a doctor, well 
below the national target of 80%. The MOH has tried to redress the shortage of rural doctors by 
appointing  assistant  doctors18 and,  more  recently,  by  intensively  educating  ethnic  college 
students to improve their grades and allow them to enter the medical university and become 
doctors.  Medical  staff  also  tends  to  disregard  poor  patients  and  often  lacks  intercultural 
communication skills in dealing with ethnic patients.  
 
11.   Access to hospital services and their quality. Life-threatening obstetric, pediatric, 
and other emergencies demand quick access to high-quality inpatient care. A 2001 study found 
two-thirds of maternal deaths occurring at home.19 Major issues are late referral and the lack of 
suitable and affordable referral services. The central highlands have 1.6 hospital beds per 1,000 
people, or half the 3.1 in all of Viet Nam. A typical provincial hospital in the central highlands has 
a bed occupancy rate of about 150%. A typical district hospital has a bed occupancy rate of 
100%. Public demand for hospital services, including from the poor, is expected to further 
increase with more public awareness and the improved range and quality of services, as well as 
with expanded health insurance coverage. Older hospitals are often small, congested, and 
rundown. The government has invested in replacing or upgrading these hospitals. However, 
several new hospitals could not be completed for lack of funds and need additional investment 
in equipment and civil works, including wastewater treatment plants.20   
 
12.  Hospitals with high bed occupancy find it difficult to maintain hygiene and infection 
control.  Overcrowding  in  the  outpatient  department  contributes  to  poor  diagnostics  and 
unnecessary admissions. On the other hand, some district hospitals are less busy for lack of 
specialists, equipment, and supplies for core services like emergency surgery, delivery, and 
neonatal and infant care. District hospitals near a provincial hospital are particularly prone to 
being bypassed or routinely referring patients to provincial hospitals. Improving district hospitals 
and referral systems will help reduce overloading at provincial hospitals.  
 
13.  Ratios of health care human resources to population in the central highlands are close 
to national ratios,  but  staff qualifications  are  much  lower. Particularly  lacking are medical 
specialists, pharmacists, senior nurses, and ethnic staff. In general, hospital staff skills need to 
be  upgraded  more  systematically  and  sustainably  using  local  capacity.  Provincial  medical 
teaching institutions are well placed to accomplish this but they need better equipment, training 
systems, and teaching and methodological skills.

14.  Provincial health systems management. In addition to gaps in access and quality, 
management  challenges  need  to  be  addressed  to  improve  the  effectiveness,  equity,  and 
efficiency of the provincial health system. The government has substantially increased financing 
for health services, but health spending continues to favor bureaucratic criteria over actual 
needs, hospital services over community health care, and investments over recurrent spending. 
Demand for high-end medical technology may further undermine future spending on basic care. 
Provincial health managers need training on health financing. Provincial governments also play 
an  important  role  in  allocating  resources  and  need  guidance  on  result-based  health  care 
investment.  A  new  tool  for  annual  planning  and  budgeting  has  been  introduced  to  better 
coordinate and target resources. This needs to be disseminated more widely in the provinces 
and  training  is  required  for  its  proper  and  effective  application.  Orienting  provincial  health 
management  more  toward  results  requires  improving  the  health  management  information 
system,  which  is  currently  fragmented  and  offers  limited  accessibility  and  usefulness  in 
decision-making. 
 
15.  In district hospitals, management support systems to help improve the quality of services 
are weak in terms of facility management, infection control and waste management, information 
management, building and equipment maintenance, procurement and inventory management, 
and financial management. Managers make insufficient use of management tools, standards, 
and data, and lack opportunities to improve their management skills.21    
 
16.  Further, a major concern in the region is the lack of information and public awareness on 
health issues, particularly among women, the poor, and ethnic groups. Unsafe practices such as 
child delivery without skilled assistance and lack of hygiene at home are common. Major issues 
are the lack of IEC specially designed for women, the poor, and ethnic groups, compounded by 
deficient communication skills among health care providers. Awareness campaigns for health 
that deliver culture- and gender-sensitive messages are needed. Training should focus as well 
on improving health care staff skills for culture-sensitive communication.  
 
17.  Lessons. The earlier project, implemented from 2004 to 2011, helped improve hospital 
services, staff capacity, and affordability for the poor in the central highlands.22 It (i) upgraded 
and equipped one provincial hospital, two secondary medical schools, nine preventive and IEC 
centers, and 12 district hospitals and wastewater treatment plants; (ii) provided training for 
doctors and nurses; and (iii) piloted a health equity fund for the poor. The project completion 
report rated the project successful and recommended (i) targeting the poor and ethnic groups, 
(ii) focusing on more local facilities, (iii) improving resource allocation, (iv) improving health 
sector  planning,  (v) ensuring  counterpart  funding  for  infrastructure,  (vi)  preparing  long-term 
training plans, (vii) improving procurement systems, and (viii) improving project monitoring. 23 
The  proposed  project  was  designed  taking  into  consideration  these  lessons  from  the  first 
project.  
 
18.  ADB strategy. ADB’s country partnership strategy 2012−2015 emphasizes support for 
disadvantaged  populations  to  ensure  inclusive  growth  and  thereby  increase  social  and 
economic  benefits.24It  includes  support  to  health  care  in  disadvantaged  areas  to  ensure

the MDGs and addressing governance and financing issues in the health sector jointly with 
other development partners.25 
  
19.  Development coordination. In addition to ADB’s earlier project (footnote 22), the Japan 
International Cooperation Agency and the governments of the Republic of Korea and Spain 
supported hospital development in the central highlands. The European Union and Atlantic 
Philanthropies also supported community health care. Pathfinder and the Government of the 
Netherlands have supported the development of model CHS services. ADB and global funding 
agencies also support the control of HIV and of neglected and emerging infectious diseases. 
Coordination of development assistance in the central highlands is undertaken mainly through 
dialogue between the MOH and development partners at the national level.26  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
20.  The impact will be improved health and nutrition in the central highlands, in particular for 
women, children, the poor, and ethnic groups. The outcome will be the increased use of health 
services, in particular maternal and child health services in district hospitals, ICPs, and CHSs. 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
21.  The project will have three key outputs: (i) improved access and quality of community 
health  care,  (ii)  increased  access  and  quality  of  hospital  services,  and  (iii)  strengthened 
provincial health system management. The project will provide support in the five provinces of 
the central highlands, in particular for activities to improve health care for the poor, ethnic 
groups, and women and children living in remote communities.  
 
1.  Output 1: Improved Access and Quality of Community Health Care 
 
22.  The project will support improved community health care with a focus on maternal and 
child care for the poor and ethnic groups in rural locations. With support from district health 
offices, at least 20% of the rural CHSs will be selected to work with surrounding villages to 
improve  community  health  care  through  outreach  services,  including  health  and  nutrition 
promotion and maternal and child care. 27 The project builds on and expands earlier programs 
for improving basic health care using standard packages and quality assurance mechanisms28 
and will help improve the health system and address gaps in resources.  
 
23.  The project will provide (i) 6-month pre-service training for VHWs and VBAs to ensure 
that all villages in the catchment areas of targeted CHSs have adequate VHWs and VBAs; and            
(ii) refresher courses for VHWs and VBAs in the selected provinces, with priority given to 
catchment areas of selected CHSs as appropriate. It will provide toolkits for all eligible VHWs 
and delivery kits for all eligible VBAs. It will also support IEC campaigns on health and nutrition. 
Prior to these campaigns, the project will conduct a knowledge, attitudes, and practices study in 
the villages and produce IEC materials appropriate to the sociocultural context of the region. 
Eleven vehicles will be provided to districts lacking transportation to improve CHS supervision 
and outreach services.

6  
 
24.  The project will build and equip 24 CHSs, replace and equip 10 ICPs, upgrade and equip 
30 CHSs, and complete the equipment of other selected CHSs and ICPs. It will support 150 
scholarships for ethnic students in medical technician or nursing degree courses and support 
health quality improvement through in-service skills training for CHS and ICP staff in hospitals. 
Staff will also be trained to be aware of sociocultural barriers, in IEC skills, and caring for ethnic 
patients.  
  
2.  Output 2: Increased Access and Quality of Hospital Services  
 
25.  The project will support district hospitals toward improving access to referral services 
and reducing the overloading of provincial hospitals. A comprehensive approach, focusing on 
delivery of standard packages of health services, will be followed to improve hospital services 
and strengthen quality assurance. The project will help upgrade eight district hospitals, build one 
new district hospital, equip about 27 district hospitals and 3 provincial hospitals (including for 
emergency services), and provide 28 ambulances. It will help repair and maintain water supply 
and sanitation in all eligible district hospitals.  
  
26.  To improve service quality, the project will support system development and training in 
infection control, waste management, and quality assurance for selected staff in all district 
hospitals. It will support (i) short-term technical skills training for nurses, laboratory assistants, 
and  maintenance  specialists  in  all  district  hospitals; (ii) training  162 specialist  doctors; (iii) 
upgrading 125 assistant doctors and assistant pharmacists into doctors and pharmacists; and 
(iv) providing short courses for 111 specialist doctors. Priority will be given to female and ethnic 
candidates.  
  
3.  Output 3: Strengthened Provincial Health System Management 
 
27.  The  project  will  help  improve  provincial  and  district  health  management  systems. 
Activities will include orientation for provincial governments and local leaders and training for 
provincial  and  district  health  managers  and  CHS  and  ICP  heads  on  annual  planning  and 
budgeting,  management  and  supervision  tools,  quality  assurance,  building  and  equipment 
maintenance, and a health management information system.  
 
28.  Capacity  building  in  public  health  and  hospital  management  will  include  a  3-month 
certificate course for provincial and district health office managers, CHS and ICP heads, and 
hospital  managers  in  health  services  management.  This  will  include  human  resources 
management, financial management, quality assurance, and health management information 
system,  and  mainstreaming  gender  and  ethnic  concerns.  Female  and  ethnic  staff  will  be 
prioritized. To improve training outcomes, the project will support the development of an in-
service training system, including a provincial training team and coordinator, a core group of 
teachers to improve teaching methodologies, distant learning materials, a database to identify 
staff training needs, and field assessment.   
 
29.  The project will have a central project management unit (CPMU) and five provincial 
project management units (PPMU). Staff will be trained in planning, monitoring, procurement, 
disbursement, and financial management. A project monitoring and evaluation system will be 
established. Project activities will be included in the annual operational plans of provinces, 
which will contribute to the sustainability of project benefits. The project will provide one vehicle 
for supervision by CPMU.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
32.  The MOH will be the executing agency. The project will be implemented through the 
CPMU in the MOH and five PPMUs in provincial departments of health. An MOH steering 
committee will provide project guidance and oversight. The project will be implemented in 
coordination with development partners. The implementation arrangements are summarized in 
Table 3 and described in detail in the project administration manual (PAM).31

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical  
 
33.  Technical  challenges  include  providing  health  care  in  remote  villages  and  to                                                                                                                              
ethnic groups and ensuring the procurement of high-quality civil works, equipment, and training. 
Contracting  local  institutions  is  proposed  to  help  reach  remote  villages,  and  international 
consultants to prepare engineering designs and specifications of equipment.  
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
34.  The  project  will  contribute  to  lifting  the  burden  of maternal  and  child  mortality  and 
improving the health of people in participating provinces and districts, particularly the poor and 
vulnerable, including ethnic groups living in border areas. The project is pro-poor in its focus on 
delivering and expanding health care in districts and communes. The estimated economic 
internal rate of return is 21.4%, with benefits derived mainly from beneficiaries’ productivity 
gains.32 The financial analysis assessed the recurrent cost of project investments to be below 
2% of provincial recurrent health spending, which is considered sustainable. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
35.  The MOH has substantial experience in implementing ADB-assisted projects and staff 
with experience in ADB procedures. A financial management assessment confirmed that the 
                                                
32 Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
 
MOH has adequate capacity in project implementation. No major governance issues have been 
identified in previous ADB-financed projects. CPMU and PPMU staff will receive governance 
orientation. All procurement will be posted on the project website. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy 
(1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with the government and the MOH. 
Specific policy requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM (footnote 
31). 
 
D.  Poverty and Social  
 
36.   The targeted provinces have a high proportion of poor, who have limited access to and 
use of health services, have less healthy living conditions, and have limited information on 
improving their health. The project will increase access to and the demand for good quality 
health services at both the community and district levels. This will help improve the health of 
people in the central highlands, particularly of the poor and members of ethnic groups. In turn, 
this will improve their labor productivity and reduce health expenditures.33  
 
E.  Gender Impacts 
 
37.   The  project  is  classified  under  category  I  (gender  equity  as  a  theme)  under  the 
guidelines for gender mainstreaming categories for ADB projects.34 Key gender impacts of the 
project  include  (i)  new  and  upgraded  medical  facilities  and  equipment  that  prioritize  and 
strengthen the capacity of health services to respond to women’s needs; (ii) increased skills of 
female health staff and managers at all levels; (iii) the institutionalization of gender-responsive 
and patient-focused approaches to providing health care; and (iv) increased understanding 
among women and their families of the importance of accessing health care. The gender action 
plan aligns with national and sector-specific gender equality commitments.35  
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
38.  Environment (category B). Mainly beneficial impacts are expected from the project, as 
it  will  support  the  construction,  rehabilitation,  and  operation  of  health  facilities,  including 
improved water, sanitation, and waste management systems. However, the construction of 
hospitals will cause disturbances, such as dust and noise. An initial environmental examination 
including an environment management plan has been prepared.36  
  
39.    Resettlement  (category  C).  The  project  will  not  involve  any  resettlement.  Most 
construction will take place in the existing compounds of health facilities. For new locations, 
government land has been made available without affecting any households.  
 
40.   Indigenous peoples (category B). The project has among its beneficiaries a significant 
proportion  of  ethnic  groups  who  are  among  some  of  the  poorest  and  most  marginalized 
households in Viet Nam. The indigenous peoples plan ensures that ethnic peoples’ needs will 
be analyzed and that they will participate in the project and have access to its benefits.37 The 
indigenous peoples plan has been disclosed on the ADB website.

IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
42.  The Government of Viet Nam and MOH have assured ADB that implementation of the 
project shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described in detail in the project administration manual and loan documents. The government 
has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in the loan 
agreement. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
43.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan in various 
currencies equivalent to SDR46,609,000 to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Second 
Health Care in the Central Highlands Project, from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an 
interest charge at the rate of 2.0% per annum during the grace period and thereafter; for a term 
of 25 years, including a grace period of 5 years; and such other terms and conditions as are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the 
Board.
